Quantum theory is often described as a theory of states and operations. However, this description is incomplete because it does not specify the mathematical structure of the states. In this paper, we provide a categorical description of quantum theory in which the states are elements of a category of Hilbert spaces. The axioms of the theory are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is motivated by reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. The theory is shown to be complete in the sense that every functor from the category of states to the category of sets can be extended to a state. The theory is also shown to be internally consistent in the sense that every state is a terminal object in the category of states. Finally, the theory is shown to be internally categorical in the sense that every state is equivalent to a state of the form of a Hilbert space.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes and transcriptomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a previously unknown mechanism to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2 transcription factors. We found that the viral accessory protein ORF6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain. We also show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its ability to block nuclear import. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of interferon. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. Mutations of some proton channel residues affect only Zn2+ inhibition of the voltage sensor motion, whereas mutations of other residues also affect Zn2+ inhibition of gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses. This will have important consequences for food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This will have important consequences for food security, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. We also show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will be zero under 2 °C warming for the top four maize-exporting countries, but it will increase to 70% for the United States and to 90% for China. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because species-level identification is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of LMH in African savanna biodiversity. This information is critical for predicting the consequences of LMH loss and fragmentation in a changing world.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We used data from circumnavigation cruises to show that the distribution of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is worldwide, mostly accumulating in the convergence zones of the five subtropical gyres. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface was estimated to be on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the size distribution of plastic debris, which points at important size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The ability to reproduce is a fundamental characteristic of all species. In humans, the ability to reproduce is limited by the mother’s metabolic power. In placental mammals, the mother’s metabolic power is limited by the availability of resources. All forms of external energy provisioning increase the mother’s metabolic power and reproductive output. The greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is important because it suggests that the reproductive output of placental mammals is largely determined by the amount of energy available to the mother. This is a fundamental insight for understanding the evolution of placental mammals and the origin of domestication. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of human reproduction.

The endothelium is the lining of all blood vessels and is the primary interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It controls vascular contractility, hemostasis, and inflammation and regulates the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between circulating blood and tissue. To control each function, the endothelium processes endlessly arriving requests from multiple sources using separate clusters of cells specialized to detect specific stimuli. A well-developed but poorly understood communication system operates between cells to integrate multiple lines of information and coordinate endothelial responses. Here, the nature of the communication network has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. This study provides a framework for understanding the endothelial network and its role in vascular function. It also provides a model for the design of networks in general. The findings have implications for understanding the role of the endothelium in health and disease.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders and is associated with a variety of social impairments. However, the underlying mechanisms are largely unknown. Here we show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate in a social encounter with a low-anxious rat. We identify the nucleus accumbens as a key brain region involved in this process and show that high-anxious animals are characterized by reduced mitochondrial function in this brain area. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is reversed by microinfusion of mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic explanation for the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our results are of relevance for understanding the pathophysiology of anxiety disorders and may lead to the development of new treatment strategies.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, through a free-form inverse design approach, multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties are optimally synthesized into composite structures to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. While complex in geometry and material heterogeneity, the discovered structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication with different polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) elastomers with distinct behaviors and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. To enhance programmability, the synthesized structures are heteroassembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex yet navigable responses. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is a key regulator of oxygen delivery to tissues. The Hb system is also a target of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) mediates the heterochronous down-regulation of adult hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 silencing in human erythroid cells results in a nearly complete reversal of the adult Hb expression pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This reversal is mediated by reduced protein expression of the transcription factor BCL11A. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans. This mechanism may be relevant to the development of hemoglobinopathies and to the chronologic control of Hb expression in the human embryo. This work also provides a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. This work also provides a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP was successful in reversing declines of older-forest–associated birds. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of these species, but the rate of decline accelerated on private lands where clearcutting continued. Early-seral–associated bird populations declined on federal lands, but not on private lands where clearcutting stopped. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. The NWFP is a model for policy that incorporates monitoring and adaptive management. We hope that our findings will help inform the development of similar policies in other regions.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This study demonstrates the potential of computational design of antibiotics. The design strategy presented here can be applied to other antibiotic classes. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. This architecture can be applied to other problems as well. We believe that this architecture will be useful for the community.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. However, the biological effects of this exposure on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin, phase-delays the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices. The results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YDB indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the impact hypothesis for the YDB. (Show more)

CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is unknown. Here, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and autoimmunity, which is not fatal. However, congenital deficiency is more severe. CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice has opposing effects on different autoimmune models. Thus, CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings provide insights into the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. They also suggest that CTLA-4 deficiency may be a promising therapeutic approach for autoimmune diseases.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to understand the factors that have driven their diversification. We found that the origin of beetles and angiosperms coincided with the codiversification of beetles and microbes, and that the evolution of plant-feeding beetles was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls. These findings suggest that beetles diversified rapidly following the origin of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes, and that the origin of beetles may have been driven by a combination of factors. This work provides insights into the factors that have driven the diversification of this important group of animals.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of currently available vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We applied this algorithm to a human antibody that is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Our algorithm identified CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to address the current and future challenges of the COVID-19 pandemic. The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a key question in the study of human culture. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and the design of interventions to enhance it. They also highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km, which is the largest solid body in the solar system. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much easier than that of the stable hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the dominant phase of the inner core. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also provides an explanation for the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. They also have implications for the formation of other solid bodies in the solar system. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and with increased addiction severity and craving.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are among the most mysterious aspects of the mind. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can predict the contents of people’s minds when they are reading language. This suggests that the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms are being shaped by the need to make predictions about the future. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also have implications for the neuroscience of other cognitive and neural processes.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, DL is still in its infancy, and there are many problems that it cannot solve. One of the main reasons is that the training of DL is unstable, and there is no guarantee that the trained model is stable. In this paper, we prove that there are problems in scientific computing where there is no algorithm that can train a stable model. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limitations of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This has led to a growing body of research on the topic. However, the classic experiment that is often cited as evidence for this inability has several critical design flaws. These are discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. The uncultured human pathogen M. lepromatosis is associated with diffuse lepromatous leprosy and a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a Mexican patient and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two species are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our findings suggest that M. lepromatosis is a neuropathogenic species and that the two species have been evolving together for millions of years. This study also provides a framework for the study of the evolution of the leprosy pathogen. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two pillars of quantum information theory, which is the main field of application of entanglement. However, the relation between them is still not fully understood. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in integrable systems can be completely described in terms of quasiparticles. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems, which is a long-standing open problem. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is integrable and thus provides a solvable model. Our work is a step toward a deeper understanding of the relation between entanglement and thermodynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus, which is associated with severe side effects. In this study, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine candidate that is highly protective in hamsters and has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature, which is the same temperature at which the virus replicates in humans. The vaccine candidate is also highly protective in hamsters when inoculated intranasally, which is the preferred route of administration. This study provides a proof-of-concept for a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that can be used in mass vaccination programs. Plague is a highly contagious disease that can spread through human populations by multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets, but the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is poorly understood. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to inform the development of effective control strategies for the current pandemic caused by the zoonotic coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known driver of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain power is more complex and requires a different approach. We use the largest dataset of its kind to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages. The other two major increases in the number of neurons happened in core land birds and anthropoid primates, which are two groups known for their cognitive prowess.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal and transformed cells is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a rationale for the development of TRAP1-targeted therapies. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key player in many cellular processes, including cell motility. However, how it does so is not fully understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin enhances severing of filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. This mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. We propose that it is a general mechanism that is used by other regulators of actin filament disassembly. This mechanism could be important for understanding the role of ADF/cofilin in many cellular processes.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study suggests that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. In addition, the results suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior by increasing activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for the design of interventions to reduce consumption of these beverages.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement of Madagascar. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It is also a step toward understanding the history of the Indian Ocean region.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This constitutes experimental evidence for massive-scale contagion via social networks. In contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These findings have implications for the design of social media platforms, as well as for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The ribosome is the central protein-synthesizing complex in the cell, and the mRNA sequences that direct translation are encoded in the untranslated regions of messenger RNA (mRNA). We have developed a fully reconstituted bacterial translation system and used it to study the effects of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. We find that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA can modestly alter translation speed and the rate of peptide synthesis. These findings suggest that mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on the ribosome, and that the ribosome can also be a source of mRNA modifications. Our work provides insight into the role of mRNA modifications in protein synthesis. (Show more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size is a central question in biology. We use a quantitative model to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant aquatic mammal lineages. This result is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the human respiratory tract has been attributed to a reduced antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus 1B exhibit a more efficient antiviral defense response at core body temperature than at nasal cavity temperature. This difference in defense response accounts for the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in mouse airway cells. Our findings suggest that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication in the human respiratory tract is not universal and that the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication may vary between different virus strains and cell types. Our study also identifies a potential target for the development of antiviral strategies against rhinovirus infections. (Show more)

The bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients and other individuals with compromised immune systems. It is able to cause infections by a variety of mechanisms, including the production of toxins and the formation of biofilms. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. We demonstrate that type IV pili are involved in twitching motility, a process that is important for surface attachment. We also show that type IV pili are involved in the sensing of surfaces, and that this process is mediated by the Chp chemosensory system. This system is similar to the chemotaxis system, and it regulates the production of cAMP and the expression of hundreds of genes, including key virulence factors. Our results thus demonstrate that type IV pili are used by P. aeruginosa as a sensor for surfaces, and as a regulator of surface-induced virulence. This is an important finding, as it suggests that type IV pili are involved in the sensing of a wide range of environmental signals. This may have important implications for the development of new strategies for the control of P. aeruginosa infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface waters are poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been documented in a variety of animal species, including free-living animals. However, the potential for SARS-CoV-2 to persist in free-living animals and to serve as a reservoir for continued transmission to humans is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. Our results highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This approach is critical to the development of effective strategies to mitigate the spread of the virus. Our findings have implications for the conservation of wildlife and the health of humans and animals.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and the climate. This paper examines the problems and solutions. We find that the environmental and social costs of dams are underestimated and that the benefits are overestimated. We also find that the industry is not addressing the legitimate concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of extensive research. However, the immune response in AD is still poorly understood. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in AD. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors, both at the transcript and protein levels. Importantly, we identify an inflammatory profile unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, since neighboring glial cells did not express similar molecules. Moreover, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still missing. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

MBP is a two-domain protein with a large central hydrophobic region that is difficult to fold. We have developed a method to study the folding of MBP in high structural detail. We have found that the folding of MBP proceeds in two steps. The first step is a fast compaction of the protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow folding of the globular state into the native state. The compaction step is a common feature of the folding of large proteins. The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can be tuned to exhibit critical behavior. SOC systems are characterized by a critical state, where the system is always in a state of criticality, and by a mechanism that drives the system to criticality from any initial state. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under strain without phonon instability. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis of antifungal activity of plant immune peptides is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly dynamic and has a unique structure with one α-helix and one β-sheet. It exhibited potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It also exhibited strong binding to fungal cell walls and penetrated the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by accumulation in the cytoplasm and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. This work illustrates the structural basis of antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. We used proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that female-derived proteins associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sex differences in the female reproductive tract. (Show more)

We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF receptor, glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study because of the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which will enable future studies of the human virome. We find that viruses are associated with many diseases, including cancer, autism, and HIV.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI processes. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the ACI community. The paper is expected to be of interest to the broader atmospheric science community.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The most widely accepted estimate of surface temperature in the Archean, the Earth’s earliest geological period, is 70 ± 15 °C. This estimate, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present evidence that the surface temperature of Earth decreased from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. This finding is consistent with previous estimates based on isotopic data and protein reconstruction. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the human red blood cell (RBC), the target of infection. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses the erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) to alter the biophysical properties of the RBC. We show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. These changes in the RBC are correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up new avenues for the development of new antimalarial drugs.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus disease. The brain is thought to process language by first parsing it into a tree-like structure of phrases. However, the brain’s activity during this process is poorly understood. Here, we used intracranial recordings to show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with the idea that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to extract the structure of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the brain’s processing of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness to the Wnt signal. We believe that this differential regulation is a common feature of redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region in the control of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc). Stimulation of the LH causes dopamine neurons in the VTA to release dopamine, which in turn inhibits dopamine neurons in the SNc. This inhibition of SNc dopamine neurons is necessary for the stimulation-induced eating. We also found that stimulation of the LH causes dopamine neurons in a more caudal region of the hypothalamus to release dopamine, which in turn inhibits neurons in the locus coeruleus (LC). This inhibition of LC neurons is necessary for the stimulation-induced eating. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for understanding the neural mechanisms of overeating and obesity.

Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen in agriculture, and could be extended to other nitrogen-fixing symbioses. It could also be used to study the evolution of symbiosis. The Peruvian Amazon is the most deforested region in the world, and the rate of deforestation is increasing. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and deter deforestation, but the effectiveness of these alerts in deterring deforestation is unknown. We study a community-based monitoring program that uses remote-sensed alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced deforestation, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but all are part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body by outsourcing hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna, which is more sensitive to acoustic waves than the spider’s body. The spider can detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of hearing in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study provides insights into the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic flow detectors. It also provides a unique model for studying the evolution of extended and regenerative sensing. This study will be of interest to biologists, engineers, and physicists.

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. We also find that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51 °C and all particles 0.73 °C of warming. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. Our results are relevant for the upcoming 2015 United Nations climate change conference.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed over 3 million lives worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to vaccines. We report a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for vaccine design and manufacturing. This variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. This engineered RBD variant is a potential tool for vaccine design and manufacturing, and its use in combination with other vaccine candidates may further improve global access to vaccines. This work is a step toward a more equitable distribution of vaccines. (Show more)

The ligand-receptor complex of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) is implicated in the development of several cancer types. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/Ltk and ALKAL/Ltk are activated by ALKALs. We further demonstrate that zebrafish ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Finally, we show that ALKALs are required for the development of neural crest-derived tissues in vivo. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALK/Ltk and ALKAL/Ltk in neural crest development. This study provides a link between ALK/Ltk and ALKAL/Ltk in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. This is of interest for the understanding of the role of ALK/Ltk in cancer and for the development of new therapies for neuroblastoma.

The emergence of Yersinia pestis as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. However, the time of its origin and its early evolution have been difficult to study due to the scarcity of ancient genomes. Here, we present 17 ancient Y. pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age. We show that the plague pathogen underwent a series of evolutionary steps before its emergence, and that it rapidly spread across Eurasia. We also show that the plague pathogen diversified in the Bronze Age in Iberia, a region that was previously thought to be a late adopter of the plague pathogen. These data provide insights into the early evolution of the plague pathogen and its spread across Eurasia. (Show more)

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with SOC storage, as intensive crop production on grassland-derived Mollisols has liberated massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated carbon in Mollisols. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural systems. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and cause disease outbreaks. We used this framework to prioritize 887 wildlife viruses for further investigation. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work is a step toward a more informed approach to the prevention of future viral spillover and outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar red nectar in the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait that is likely under selection for pollinator attraction. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in the plant–pollinator interaction. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, functional variants indicate that they also differed in visible characteristics. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Examination of the panel of functional loci also revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings are important for understanding the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and for developing effective countermeasures against future bat coronavirus threats to human health. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can be evolved to have catalytic activity, but the activity of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template has not been demonstrated. Here, we describe the construction of such a polymerase ribozyme and its use to synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase ribozyme can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods is a key determinant of economic outcomes and that urban planners and policymakers should consider the physical appearance of neighborhoods when planning for the future. Our method can be used to measure the physical appearance of neighborhoods in other cities and can be extended to measure the physical appearance of other types of urban features. Our method can also be used to measure the physical appearance of other urban features, such as parks, schools, and businesses.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the early stage. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. This study provides a new treatment strategy for COVID-19.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in the Northern Hemisphere, and that this change is driven by the evolutionary history of the species that are most affected. We also show that the evolutionary history of frost damage is different in different regions of the world, and that this history can be used to forecast the future evolution of frost damage. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. We found that Th17 cells could directly transition to Th1-like cells and support the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis. The dual mechanisms of action described here may explain the complex relationship between Th17 cells and inflammatory bowel disease. These results also have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, but also by non-motor neuron-specific toxic effects. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-specific astrocytes from living ALS patients. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for therapeutics. This will accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new treatments.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now demonstrate that Anaplasma modifies the tick microbiota to more efficiently colonize the vector. We show that Anaplasma induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which encodes a protein with several properties, including the ability to alter bacterial biofilm formation. IAFGP perturbs the tick gut microbiota, which influences the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier—critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector microbiome and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The origin of the avian tail and the evolution of the avian body plan are among the most important evolutionary questions in biology. The discovery of a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis, adds important information about the origin of the avian tail and the evolution of the avian body plan. Jinguofortis is notable for its mosaic evolution, in which the tail and the body plan evolved through the combination of plesiomorphic nonavian theropod features and more derived avian features. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of feedbacks. In this paper, we show that there is a feedback in the stratosphere that increases water vapor in the stratosphere with temperature there. This feedback is important because it increases the water vapor in the stratosphere, which in turn increases the temperature there. This is a positive feedback, and it is important because it increases the climate sensitivity of the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments. In some species, the absorption spectrum of the pigments is altered by the presence of specific proteins, which are called color-modifying proteins. These proteins are found in a wide range of species, from humans to frogs. We describe the molecular and functional basis of the color of frogs, and show that the color of frogs is determined by the absorption spectrum of a specific protein. This study provides a molecular and functional basis for the evolution of color in vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a key feature of the tumor microenvironment, and is associated with increased breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) numbers. We report that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which demethylates N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modifications on mRNA. ALKBH5 expression is increased in BCSCs, and is HIF-dependent. ALKBH5 overexpression increases the percentage of BCSCs, and knockdown of ALKBH5 expression decreases the BCSC phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and mediates enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. This study provides insight into the molecular mechanisms that regulate BCSC numbers, and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for breast cancer. The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term “uterine vellum” is often used to describe this practice, but it is not clear whether this term is appropriate. We present a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. This method is based on the extraction of proteins from the parchment surface using a PVC eraser. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. This method is noninvasive and can be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the field. It could be used to identify the origin of the parchment used in the production of the first pocket Bibles. This would have been a significant discovery, as it would have shown that the Bible was not a product of the 19th century.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable immediately preceding the extinction, and the recovery of the carbon cycle persisted for ∼500 ka. These results will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is applied to study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs. COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for the total US population and by race and ethnicity. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings highlight the need for public health interventions to reduce the racial disparities in COVID-19 morbidity and mortality.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are widely used in chemistry. However, the chemical properties of atoms are not constant, but change with pressure. In this work, we calculate the pressure-dependent chemical properties of atoms, and show that the chemical properties of atoms change dramatically under pressure. We also show that the pressure-dependent chemical properties can be used to predict and explain the exotic chemical phenomena under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are highly uncertain, and the role of human ignitions and suppression is less clear. We show that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity, which could offset some of the warming caused by human emissions. This is especially true under lower emission scenarios. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions and fire suppression in driving future fire regimes, and the potential for these to influence the climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a circadian manner. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan-provisioning strategy may be used by other animal hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbial communities. The study of text data is a rapidly growing field. However, the analysis of text data is often limited to simple statistics. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and draws on the strengths of topic modeling and word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that our method will be of interest to researchers in many fields.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This study shows that the introduction of the plague into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather the result of repeated introductions, each of which was preceded by a climate-driven rodent dispersal. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for a variety of species. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that has been described as a “melting” syndrome. The disease is caused by a virus that is transmitted by starfish (Asteroidea). We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it has been present on the Pacific coast of North America for at least 72 y. This study provides evidence that viruses can be responsible for mass mortality events of marine invertebrates. It also highlights the importance of viruses in marine ecosystems.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestries, with a recent settlement of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia. In addition, we find that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar. It is a unique contribution to the understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean.
